title: 107_s1017
content:
The "Bridges to the Cuban People Act of 2001" allows for the export of food and medicines to Cuba, exempting them from trade restrictions. The "Bridges to the Cuban People Act of 2001" exempts agricultural commodities, farm machinery, medicine, and medical devices from trade restrictions with Cuba, except for specific cases outlined in the law. The "Bridges to the Cuban People Act of 2001" exempts agricultural commodities, farm machinery, medicine, and medical devices from trade restrictions with Cuba. U.S.C. 1702 allows prohibitions or restrictions on machinery or equipment if it poses a threat to national security. Subsection (a) supersedes the Trade Sanctions Reform and Export Enhancement Act of 2000. SEC. 102. REMOVAL OF CERTAIN PROHIBITIONS ON VESSELS ENTERING UNITED STATES PORTS. Section 1706(b) of the Cuban Democracy Act of 1992 shall not apply to vessels transporting items permitted for export to Cuba. SEC. 103. STUDY AND REPORT RELATING TO EXPORT PROMOTION AND CREDIT PROGRAMS FOR CUBA. The Secretary of Agriculture will conduct a study on US agricultural export promotion and credit programs to promote consumption of US agricultural commodities in Cuba. A report with study results and recommendations for legislation will be submitted to relevant committees within 90 days of enactment. The Secretary of Agriculture will conduct a study on US agricultural export promotion and credit programs to boost consumption of US agricultural commodities in Cuba. The President must report to Congress within 6 months of the Act's enactment on sales of agricultural commodities, machinery, medicines, and medical devices to Cuba. The report should include volume and dollar amounts of exports, types of goods exported, and any indication of misuse of medical exports. SEC. 105. DEFINITIONS. This section defines terms like agricultural commodity, medical device, and medicine. The President shall not regulate or prohibit travel to, from, or within Cuba by US nationals or lawful permanent residents, including transactions incident to such travel. This supersedes any other provision of law. Transactions related to travel to or from Cuba include importation of personal baggage, payment of living expenses, acquisition of goods or services for personal use, and arrangement or facilitation of travel. Transactions related to travel to, from, or within Cuba include nonscheduled air, sea, or land voyages, banking transactions, and exclusion of certain goods for personal consumption. The prohibition on importing goods for personal consumption from Cuba does not apply in certain circumstances such as during war, armed hostilities, or credible threats to public health or safety of US nationals in Cuba. This section applies to actions taken by the President before the enactment of this Act. The Act repeals certain provisions of law, defines terms such as "lawfully admitted for permanent residence" and "national of the United States." The Act defines terms like "national of the United States" according to the Immigration and Nationality Act. TITLE III--SCHOLARSHIPS FOR CERTAIN CUBAN NATIONALS

SEC. 301. SCHOLARSHIPS FOR GRADUATE STUDY. The President is authorized to provide scholarships for Cuban nationals seeking graduate study in various fields. Preference is given to individuals not affiliated with the Cuban government or communist party. This authority supersedes any other provision of law. For fiscal years 2002 through 2006, the Act of 1961 authorizes funding for scholarships for Cuban nationals pursuing graduate study, with varying amounts allocated each year for a specific number of scholarships. TITLE IV--MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS

SEC. 401. WAIVER AUTHORITY WITH RESPECT TO THE PUBLIC LAW 104-114.

The President can waive sanctions and restrictions on assistance under Public Law 104-114 to promote democracy in Cuba. The President can also waive grounds of inadmissibility for certain aliens to further the national economic interest of the United States.

SEC. 402. PROHIBITION ON LIMITING ANNUAL REMITTANCES. SEC. 402 prohibits limiting annual remittances to Cuba by individuals under U.S. jurisdiction, with exceptions for money laundering offenses. Prohibition or restriction on trade or financial transactions with Cuba does not apply to new drugs, biological products, devices, or approved drugs under certain applications submitted to the Secretary of Health and Human Services. Prohibition or restriction on trade or financial transactions with Cuba does not apply to new drugs, biological products, or devices approved under specific applications submitted to the Secretary of Health and Human Services. These include drugs under section 505 of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act, biological products under section 351 of the Public Health Service Act, and devices cleared for marketing under section 510(k) or approved under section 515 of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act. SEC. 404 prohibits the use of funds to enforce unilateral sanctions by the US on exports of goods or services exclusively for children, unless imposed through an agreement with other countries.
